citeinfo.title: Soil-hydraulic properties as a function of burn severity for 2013, 2015, and 2017 in the area affected by the 2013 Black Forest Fire, Colorado USA

descript.purpose: This project investigated recovery of soil properties that influence flash flood generation in the area affected by the 2013 Black Forest Fire in Colorado, USA. Data were collected for three temporal snapshots (2013, 2105, and 2017) during a time period of four years following the wildfire to assess remaining flood hazards. Data include bulk density, loss on ignition, ground cover, soil particle size, soil-hydraulic properties, and simple infiltration modeling.

theme.themekey: wildfire, colorado, wildland fire, soil properties, soil-hydraulic properties

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: None. Users are advised to read the data set's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.

cntaddr.address: Box 25046, MS410, Denver Fed. Center, Bldg. 53

attracc.attraccr: Soil hydraulic properties of sorptivity and field-saturated hydraulic conductivity were estimated using a tension infiltrometer. Values for 2013 are the values reported by Moody et al. (2016) and are the Differentiated Linearization method values for which both sorptivity and field-saturated hydraulic conductivity are positive. The values reported for 2015 and 2017 are the average values using the Cumulative Linearization and Differentiated Linearization processing methods with the restriction that both sorptivity and field-saturated hydraulic conductivity must be positive to be included. No additional tests were conducted to assess the accuracy of values.

dataqual.logic: Data match details provided and values fall within expected ranges. Data has been checked for duplication and omission.
dataqual.complete: The dataset only represents occurrences within the area impacted by the 2013 Black Forest Fire in Colorado, USA. Values for 2013 are the values reported by Moody et al. (2016) and are the Differentiated Linearization method values for which both sorptivity and field-saturated hydraulic conductivity are positive.The values reported for 2015 and 2017 are the average values using the Cumulative Linearization and Differentiated Linearization processing methods with the restriction that both sorptivity and field-saturated hydraulic conductivity must be positive to be included.The datasets are complete for 2013, 2015 and 2017,with the exception that site BF2 was not sampled in 2017 because the site was compromised by soil damage from salvage logging.

horizpa.horizpar: Horizontal locations are accurate to within recreational GPS accuracy (several meters).

vertacc.vertaccr: Vertical locations are accurate to within recreational GPS accuracy (5 meters)

procstep.procdesc:
Soil hydraulic properties of sorptivity and field-saturated hydraulic conductivity were estimated using a tension infiltrometer. Values for 2013 are the values reported by Moody et al. (2016) and are the Differentiated Linearization method values for which both sorptivity and field-saturated hydraulic conductivity are positive. The values reported for 2015 and 2017 are the average values using the Cumulative Linearization and Differentiated Linearization processing methods with the restriction that both sorptivity and field-saturated hydraulic conductivity must be positive to be included. The methods used to estimate sorptivity and field-saturated hydraulic conductivity are described in Moody et al. (2016).
Moody, J. A., Ebel, B. A., Nyman, P., Martin, D. A., Stoof, C., & McKinley, R. (2016). Relations between soil hydraulic properties and burn severity. International Journal of Wildland Fire, 25(3), 279-293.

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data for soil-hydraulic properties of field-saturated hydraulic conductivity and sorptivity. 2013 data are from the Differentiated Linearization method data from Moody et al. (2016) for which both sorptivity and Kfs are positive.

attrdomv.udom: Soil sample identification, name of the soil sample from the 2013 Black Forest Fire

attr.attrdef: Site name where soil sample was collected. Sites were chosen based upon remotely-sensed burn severity classification.
Field-saturated hydraulic conductivity, Kfs, (mm per hour), Differentiated Linearization method data from Moody et al. (2016) for which both sorptivity and Kfs are positive.
Sorptivity, (mm per square root hours), Differentiated Linearization method data from Moody et al. (2016) for which both sorptivity and Kfs are positive.

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data for soil-hydraulic properties of field-saturated hydraulic conductivity and sorptivity. Differentiated Linearization and Cumulative Linearization method data for which both sorptivity and Kfs are positive are included along with the average of these two methods. Data for 2015.

Differentiated Linearization and Cumulative Linearization method data for which both sorptivity and Kfs are positive are included along with the average of these two methods. Data for 2017.

overview.eaover: Soil hydraulic properties of sorptivity and field-saturated hydraulic conductivity were estimated using a tension infiltrometer. Values for 2013 are the values reported by Moody et al. (2016) and are the Differentiated Linearization method values for which both sorptivity and field-saturated hydraulic conductivity are positive.The values reported for 2015 and 2017 are the average values using the Cumulative Linearization and Differentiated Linearization processing methods with the restriction that both sorptivity and field-saturated hydraulic conductivity must be positive to be included. Note that site BF2 was not sampled in 2017 because the site was compromised by soil damage from salvage logging.
overview.eadetcit: Ebel., B.A., Moody, J.A., Martin, D.A. 2021. Soil-physical and soil-hydraulic properties as a function of burn severity for 2013, 2015, and 2017 in the area affected by the 2013 Black Forest Fire, Colorado USA U.S. Geological Survey Data Release. https://doi.org/10.5066/P9A88C67

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
